metadata.title: Markup & Margin Calculator
metadata.description: Calculate selling price, markup percentage, and gross margin from cost or price inputs. Includes conversions between markup and margin and guidance anchored to authoritative standards and business practice.

introduction: Use this calculator to compute selling price, markup percentage, and gross margin from cost or price inputs. It supports converting between markup and margin and shows equivalent values so you can align pricing with profit targets and accounting practice.

Formulas used here are standard in finance and retail pricing: markup is profit relative to cost, margin is profit relative to selling price. This tool is intended for planning and analysis; always verify final pricing against taxes, fees, and local regulations.
methodology: Key formulas implemented: markup (%) = ((price - cost) / cost) * 100; selling price = cost * (1 + markup_decimal); margin (%) = ((price - cost) / price) * 100.

Conversion between markup and margin follows algebraic identities: margin = markup / (1 + markup) when values are expressed as decimals, and markup = margin / (1 - margin). The calculator evaluates these expressions using inputs you provide and displays formatted outputs.

Values are calculated using basic arithmetic and presented as currency or percentage. For financial reporting and tax filings, round and record values according to your accounting standards and consult a qualified advisor where needed.

faqs.question: What is the difference between markup and margin?
faqs.answer: Markup measures profit as a percentage of cost. Margin measures profit as a percentage of selling price. They are related but not equal; margin = markup / (1 + markup) when both are expressed as decimals.

faqs.question: When should I use markup versus margin?
faqs.answer: Use markup when you target a specific increase over cost (common in supplier-to-retailer pricing). Use margin when you need profit as a share of selling price (common in financial reporting and retail KPIs).

faqs.question: How should I round results for invoices and reports?
faqs.answer: Round according to your accounting and legal requirements. Common practice is to round currency to two decimal places for customer prices and to one or two decimal places for percentage points depending on internal policy. Keep consistent rounding rules for reporting.

faqs.question: Do I need to include taxes, shipping, or fees in the cost?
faqs.answer: Cost should include all incremental costs you want recovered by the price (product cost, import duties, shipping, handling). Sales tax is typically added on top of selling price where applicable; check local tax guidance and include regulatory considerations when finalizing prices.

faqs.question: Are there regulatory considerations for pricing?
faqs.answer: Yes. Price controls, anti-gouging rules, and consumer protection laws vary by jurisdiction. For businesses operating in the United States, consult federal and state guidance and the Small Business Administration for compliance recommendations.
